bibl.title: Letter from Wickliffe Rose to Laura Armistead Carter, February 25, 1921

div1.p: Rose writes that yellow fever in Peru is controllable but may spread. Henry Rose Carter will stay if needed, but he is unfit for field work.

div1.head: Letter from Wickliffe Rose to Laura Armistead Carter, February 25, 1921

February 25, 1921
Dear Miss Carter:
div1.p:
A further message from your father has been re-
ceived as follows:

FEVER IN SEVERAL TOWNS DEPARTMENT LAMBAYEQUE
OF SOME MONTHS DURATION STEGOMYIA NUMEROUS
EVERYWHERE UNLESS CONTROLLED WILL SPREAD
SOUTH TO LIBERTAD AND BEYOND CONTROLLABLE
NOW WORK UNDER WAY PRESIDENT WOULD WEL-
COME ASSISTANCE AND WOULD LIKE TO KNOW DE-
TAILS I HAD NOT PURPOSED REMAINING BUT WILL
IF ESSENTIAL TO SECURE AID I AM UNFIT FOR
FURTHER FIELD SERVICE HANSON ENTIRELY COM-
PETENT WILL BE IN ABSOLUTE CHARGE OF EPIDEMIC
AND WILL REMAIN IN FIELD CABLE IF I SHOULD
STAY OTHERWISE SAIL MARCH EIGHT CAN RE-
MAIN LONGER WITH LITTLE INCONVENIENCE IF DE-
SIRED

You will be interested to know that the Executive
Committee of the Board voted to make an appropriation of
funds for yellow fever work in Peru. I feel, however, that
your father should not be asked to remain there longer, and
have cabled him to that effect.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Wickliffe Rose. Miss Laura Armistead Carter
The Lonsdale - Apartment 206
Washington DC
